awd_titl_txt: AGS-PRF:  A Study of the Onset of Explosive Magnetic Energy Release
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a 2-year postgraduate research fellowship project to investigate multi-scale processes that drive magnetic reconnection in magnetic configurations relevant to the solar corona and to the Earth's Magnetosphere.  Results from global magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) simulations will be used as input to kinetic scale calculations of reconnection.  The kinetic simulations will then be analyzed for feedback to the global evolution, in particular to address key issues such as energy partition and particle acceleration.  Specifically, the Principal Investigator (PI) will analyze the evolution of extended current sheets from global simulations of Earth's Magnetotail and Coronal Mass Ejection (CME)/solar flare events.  Drivers for kinetic simulations will be determined from the dynamics near the primary reconnection sites, and will then be implemented in a high performance Particle-in-Cell (PIC) code.  From the kinetic simulations, the energy budgets and the particle distributions will be calculated.  These will be (i) compared with magnetospheric and solar data, where possible, as a check of the validity of the kinetic model, and (ii) used for determining a "kinetic resistivity" model that can then be put back into global MHD simulations.

This research project is perceived as an achievable intermediate step in understanding the multi-scale physical couplings in processes involving magnetic reconnection. It represents a pioneering, first-time investigation, in particular for solar events.  As reconnection is a fundamental plasma physics phenomenon, the results of the effort will have broad impacts far beyond solar and magnetospheric physics.  The PI is a recent PhD graduate and this research project will support the continued training and career advancement of an early-career female scientist in the Atmospheric and Geospace sciences

por.por_cntn:
The primary focus of this work was to examine the effects of magnetic field shearing on kinetic scale systems relevant to the solar corona. This is critical to global space weather modeling as shearing is responsible for magnetic reconnection which 1) drives space weather events and 2) is inherently a kinetic process.  The implementation of this shear driver is the first of its kind in a plasma kinetic code. The driver was successfully implemented and benchmarked with a Parker solar wind condition. It has also been used to drive coronal loop-like eruption. Preliminary studies of magnetic reconnection have been carried out. Reconnection has been driven with a range of strengths. The most significant result is that strong driving self consistently creates both current sheets and magnetic islands.

 

         The intellectual merit of this study is that magnetic reconnection is the underlying physical mechanism driving explosive space weather disturbances from the Sun to Earth. Analysis of events on the global, MHD scale has led to the understanding that local, kinetic processes are critical for the actual flux breaking that produces the reconnection. Global models for initiation of solar eruptions and magnetospheric responses have important limitations. They cannot resolve the critical microphysics that controls the reconnection rate, while kinetic models cannot capture the large-scale topology and boundary conditions responsible for the large magnetic energy release. Thus, multiscale coupling is a necessary step to advance our understanding of the critical energy transfer processes that drive geospace activity. How this coupling occurs is a compelling scientific question for the Atmosphere and Geospace Science (AGS) Environment. There are major unsolved challenges to directly patching MHD and kinetic models together. This work is a pioneering, first-time investigation, in particular for solar events.

The broader impacts of this work are that study of magnetic reconnection in the Sun-Earth system is an interdisciplinary endeavor. The reconnection site, a global-scale current sheet, is a self-similar magnetic configuration seen at the sun, at the Earth, and along the path between. Therefore, examination of this on the kinetic scale will have a broad impact across the geospace and solar fields. Reconnection is responsible for the explosive energy release in the space weather chain of events coupling the Sun to Earth, and kinetic processes govern the reconnection. This study is crucial for national and commercial assets subject to space weather conditions. The proposed work builds from and strengthens the collaborative Space Weather Program between government agencies, NSF and NASA, and academic institutions, for example the University of New Hampshire (UNH). Results were shared with the scientific community and with the general public in NSF/EPSCoR states. This award was essential to the continued support and training of an early career female scientist in the Atmosphere and Geospace Sciences (AGS).
